Award.AwardTitle: RI: Small: Collaborative Research: Bio-inspired Collaborative Sensing with Novel Gliding Robotic Fish

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration: Monitoring and understanding aquatic environments is critical to water sustainability. The goal of this award is to establish a theoretical framework and provide an enabling technology for robust underwater collaborative sensing with small, inexpensive robots. Inspired by the source-seeking behavior of live fish, computationally efficient algorithms are developed for cooperative tracing of the gradients of environmental fields, and their robustness is analyzed in the presence of localization error and changing communication topology. The algorithms are experimentally validated in thermal source seeking and tracing with a group of energy-efficient and highly maneuverable gliding robotic fish, which are enhanced in this project with optical communication and localization capabilities. Advanced controllers are developed for these robots to realize three-dimensional maneuvering and to track reference paths planned through collaborative sensing algorithms. This award offers fundamental understanding of limits and robustness properties of collaborative sensing by resource-limited robots, and contributes to the knowledge base in underwater communication and ranging for small robots. It enables technological advances for persistent sampling of versatile aquatic environments including coastal waters, lakes, and rivers, with a myriad of applications such as oil spill response, ecological monitoring, and port and drinking water security. The findings from this project are disseminated through publications, software sharing, and technology commercialization. The project provides interdisciplinary training opportunities for students, including those from underrepresented groups. Outreach activities, including museum/aquarium exhibits and teacher training, are developed to pique the interest of K-12 students, teachers, and the public in science and engineering.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project was to establish a theoretical framework and an enabling technology for realizing robust underwater collaborative sensing with small, inexpensive robots that are subject to power, computing, and communication constraints. This was a collaborative research project with Georgia Tech as the partner institution. The primary tasks of the Michigan State University team included: (a) enhancing gliding robotic fish, a novel class of underwater robots that combine advantages of robotic fish and underwater gliders, with optical communication and localization capabilities to enable underwater collaboration, and (b) developing new advanced controllers for gliding robotic fish, to realize swimming-based and gliding-based maneuvering in 3D space and to track the reference paths planned through collaborative sensing algorithms.

This award contributed to the improvement of gliding robotic fish; in particular, it facilitated the development of generation-2 gliding robotic fish, which featured a modular architecture for sensors and could be easily opened for diagnosis and service. Prototypes GRACE 2.0 and GRACE 2.1 were developed and field-tested in Higgins Lake, Michigan. This project also led to advances in light-emitting diode (LED)-based wireless communication, a promising low-power, high data-rate alternative to acoustic communication in the underwater environment. New active alignment control mechanisms based on extended Kalman filtering were introduced to sustain LED communication despite the underlying robot movement. In addition, the line-of-sight (LOS) requirement for LED communication was also exploited for triangulation-based localization, resulting in a novel paradigm of Simultaneous Localization and Communication (SLAC) for mobile robots.

This award resulted in a number of advances in the control of gliding robotic fish, including a nonlinear passivity-based controller for stabilization of gliding using a whale tail-like control surface, a sliding mode controller for simultaneous stabilization of pitch and yaw motions, and a differential geometry approach to characterization and control of the spiraling motion in 3D space. In addition, an integrative approach to the sampling of water columns was proposed, which combined inverse compensation and H-infinity control for spiral control in the water column and utilized sliding mode control for adjusting heading during column transition. This approach was field-tested in sampling 20 water columns for harmful algae in Wintergreen Lake, Michigan, and the results showed that the algae concentration was heterogeneous in all directions. Algorithms for collaborative control and informative sampling of gliding robotic fish were also developed.   

This award also advanced the analysis and design of robotic fish in general, especially when fins (tail or pectoral fins) involved flexible elements. For example, a model for predicting flexible tail-actuated robotic fish dynamics was developed; for the rigid tail case, an average model suitable for control design was developed. The role of pectoral fin flexibility in the tradeoff between speed and mechanical efficiency was explored through modeling and analysis. Furthermore, two different types of flexible and passive joints for pectoral fins were developed to realize net thrust under symmetric motor movement during power and recovery strokes. Finally, a stiffness-tunable robotic fin was developed by exploiting electro-rheological fluids, a class of smart materials.

Collectively, this award contributed to 11 published journal publications (2 more under review), 23 published conference papers (3 more under review), 3 PhD dissertations, and 3 MS theses. The results from the award were also disseminated through Youtube videos, invited talks, and public lectures. The project provided training opportunities for 7 PhD students, 3 MS students, 5 undergrad students, and 2 K-12 teachers. It also facilitated various outreach activities, including a museum exhibit and numerous lab tours. The project contributed to an enabling technology for cost-effective, long-duration sampling of versatile aquatic environments, such as coastal waters, lakes, ponds, and rivers, with a myriad of applications in oil spill response, ecological monitoring, and port and drinking water security, to name a few.
